title: CBT Thinking Errors (Cognitive Distortions)
summary: Recognize common thinking traps and practice clearer, kinder, and more accurate self-talk.

lessons.title: Spotting Thinking Traps
key_ideas: CBT model: thoughts influence feelings and actions; changing thinking can change outcomes.
Automatic thoughts happen fast; some are distorted habits, not facts.
Name it to tame it: labeling the distortion creates distance from it.
Slow down: ask for evidence, alternatives, and what would help right now.
examples: "My post got few likes, I’m a loser." — Explanation: A quick, global judgment based on a single metric; likely labeling/overgeneralization.
"Boss said 'see me'—I’m in trouble." — Explanation: Assumes a negative mind reading without evidence.
"I missed one question; I’ll fail the course." — Explanation: Catastrophizing from a small setback.
"I feel guilty, so I must have done wrong." — Explanation: Emotional reasoning; feelings treated as facts.
"If I can’t do it perfectly, there’s no point." — Explanation: All-or-nothing (black-and-white) thinking.

quick_checks.question: You didn’t get a reply to a message for 2 hours and think, "They’re mad at me." What’s the best first step?
choices: Assume they’re upset and apologize repeatedly
Send three follow-ups to be sure
feedback: Assuming intent without evidence can escalate anxiety.
Excessive messaging may increase stress for both.
Extreme action from minimal data is a thinking trap.

quick_checks.question: Which question best interrupts an automatic negative thought?
choices: What’s the evidence for and against this thought?
Why does this always happen to me?
feedback: Correct—evidence review is a core CBT tool.
Assumes a pattern; may feed overgeneralization.

quick_checks.question: "I feel anxious about the presentation, so it will definitely go badly." This is mostly:
feedback: Correct—treats a feeling as proof of outcome.
Mind reading is guessing others’ thoughts.
Mental filter ignores positives, not feelings-as-facts.

quick_checks.question: What’s a helpful way to treat an automatic thought?
feedback: Obeying thoughts without checking can entrench habits.
Judging character from a thought increases shame.

quick_checks.question: A friend cancels plans once; you think, "No one really likes me." The problem is most likely:
feedback: Correct—broad conclusion from a single event.
Labeling is global negative names for self/others.
Fortune telling is predicting the future.

quick_checks.question: Which rewrite is most CBT-aligned?
choices: "I had a setback today; I can adjust and try again."
"This proves I’m not cut out for this."

minigame.title: Thought Detective
minigame.prompt: Pick the most helpful next thought: "I stumbled in the first minute of my talk."
options: "I recovered and finished; next time I’ll practice the opening more."
minigame.correct_option: "I recovered and finished; next time I’ll practice the opening more."
minigame.explanation: Accurate, specific, future-focused reframe supports learning without denial.

lessons.title: All-or-Nothing & Overgeneralization
key_ideas: All-or-nothing: seeing things in black/white (perfect or failure).
Overgeneralization: one event becomes a broad rule ("always/never").
Use specific, time-bound language and measurable criteria.
examples: "I missed the gym once; my routine is ruined." — Explanation: One lapse becomes total failure.
"I froze in one meeting; I’m bad at public speaking." — Explanation: Broad identity based on one instance.
"If I don’t ace the exam, I’m dumb." — Explanation: Intelligence reduced to a single outcome.

quick_checks.question: Pick the best reframe: "I didn’t study enough this week; I’m hopeless."
choices: "This week fell short; I’ll plan 2 shorter sessions next week."

quick_checks.question: "I made a typo in the report; it’s worthless." Identify the distortion.
Which phrase signals overgeneralization?
Best progress metric for an all-or-nothing thinker starting to run?
choices: Only run if you feel great
Wait until you can run perfectly

quick_checks.question: "I didn’t get this job; I will never get any job." This is:
feedback: Filter ignores positives; here it’s a broad claim.

quick_checks.question: Pick the language that reduces all-or-nothing thinking.

minigame.title: Scale It
minigame.prompt: You missed one workout. Choose the most helpful thought.
options: "I can restart tomorrow; one miss is expected."
minigame.correct_option: "I can restart tomorrow; one miss is expected."
minigame.explanation: Normalizing one lapse prevents the all-or-nothing spiral.

lessons.title: Mental Filter, Discounting, Magnification/Minimization (Catastrophizing)
key_ideas: Mental filter: focusing only on negatives; discounting ignores positives.
Magnification/minimization: exaggerating flaws or downplaying strengths.
Catastrophizing: leaping to the worst-case without proportionate evidence.
examples: "Nine good comments, one critique—my work is terrible." — Explanation: Mental filter ignores base rate of positives.
"Anyone could do what I did." — Explanation: Discounting legitimate strengths.
"If I stumble once, I’ll be humiliated forever." — Explanation: Catastrophizing without a realistic chain.

quick_checks.question: Which question helps counter a mental filter?
choices: What’s one thing that went well, specifically?
feedback: Correct—naming a specific positive widens attention.

quick_checks.question: "My design won the prize, but it was luck." Identify the pattern.
A good way to counter catastrophizing is to ask:
choices: What’s the literal worst possible outcome only?
What’s most likely, and how would I cope?
How do I avoid ever failing again?
Who is to blame if it happens?
feedback: Focusing only on worst case keeps anxiety high.

quick_checks.question: "I minimized my achievement by saying 'it was nothing.'" What next?
choices: Write two concrete skills you used well
feedback: Correct—naming skills builds accuracy and confidence.

quick_checks.question: "One bug in release means our product is doomed." This is mainly:
feedback: Binary thinking may be present, but the leap is key.

quick_checks.question: Best first step after a negative performance review that also includes positives:
choices: Ruminate on the weakest line only
Extract 2 strengths and 2 growth items into an action plan
Decide you’re unfit for the job

minigame.title: Reality Dials
minigame.prompt: Pick the most balanced appraisal: "Demo had one hiccup."
options: "Mostly smooth; I’ll fix that one step."
minigame.correct_option: "Mostly smooth; I’ll fix that one step."
minigame.explanation: Acknowledges both success and a fixable issue—neither magnified nor minimized.

lessons.title: Mind Reading, Fortune Telling, Labeling
key_ideas: Mind reading: assuming we know others’ thoughts without checking.
Fortune telling: predicting negative outcomes as certainties.
Labeling: using global, negative names for self/others.
examples: "They frowned, so they hate my idea." — Explanation: Mind reading ignores other reasons for a frown.
"This launch will fail; I can tell." — Explanation: Fortune telling without data.
"I messed up; I’m an idiot." — Explanation: Global self-label from a specific event.

quick_checks.question: Most CBT-aligned response to a guessed negative reaction?
choices: Ask a clarifying question or request feedback

quick_checks.question: "I failed once; I’m a failure." This is:
feedback: Binary lens often co-occurs but label is central.

quick_checks.question: A good counter to fortune telling is:
choices: Run a small test to gather data
Ask others to decide for you
feedback: Refusal to plan keeps uncertainty high.

quick_checks.question: Which rewrite reduces labeling?
choices: "I made two mistakes under time pressure; I’ll adjust my prep."

quick_checks.question: You assume a teammate is dismissive. Best next step?
choices: Ask for their view on your idea

quick_checks.question: "They didn’t laugh, so the talk was bad." Likely distortion:
feedback: No positives mentioned, but the key claim is a guess about others.
No exaggeration of a flaw stated.

minigame.title: From Label to Lesson
minigame.prompt: Pick the best shift: "I bombed—I'm useless."
options: "That didn’t go as planned; I’ll practice Q&A and try again."
minigame.correct_option: "That didn’t go as planned; I’ll practice Q&A and try again."
minigame.explanation: Moves from identity label to specific, improvable behaviors.

lessons.title: Shoulds, Personalization, Emotional Reasoning
key_ideas: Should statements: rigid rules that create pressure and guilt.
Personalization: taking excessive blame for events outside full control.
Emotional reasoning: treating feelings as facts about reality.
examples: "I should never need help." — Explanation: Rigid rule ignores normal human limits.
"The project slipped; it’s entirely my fault." — Explanation: Personalization ignores shared factors.
"I feel scared, so it must be dangerous." — Explanation: Emotional reasoning conflates feeling with fact.

quick_checks.question: Best rewrite of a "should" statement?
choices: "It would help to prepare more; nerves are normal."

quick_checks.question: "The team missed the deadline; I failed everyone." Helpful next step?
feedback: Correct—separate your part from system factors.

quick_checks.question: "I feel angry, so I’m definitely right." Mainly:
Which phrasing reduces personalization?
choices: "Here’s my part; here are external factors."

quick_checks.question: Good test against emotional reasoning in a dark parking lot:
choices: Treat fear as proof of danger
Look for external evidence (lighting, people, exits) and act accordingly
Wait for fear to vanish before acting
feedback: Waiting may be unsafe or impractical.

quick_checks.question: "I should never need rest." Best CBT response?
choices: Notice the rule and replace with a flexible guideline about rest and effort
feedback: Correct—flexible, humane standard reduces guilt and burnout.
Blame doesn’t add rest or clarity.

minigame.title: From Should to Could
minigame.prompt: Pick the flexible rewrite: "I should always perform perfectly."
options: "It would help to practice; I aim for steady progress."
minigame.correct_option: "It would help to practice; I aim for steady progress."
minigame.explanation: Shifts from rigid rules to helpful, achievable guidance.

creator_challenge.title: Thought Record & Reframe
creator_challenge.instructions: Complete a one-page thought record: 1) Situation (facts). 2) Automatic thought (exact words). 3) Feelings (0–100%). 4) Distortion(s) present. 5) Evidence for/against. 6) Balanced alternative thought. 7) Action you will take. Submit your final version.
